00046 #ifndef _FC_UTIL_H_
00047 #define _FC_UTIL_H_

00050 extern "C" {
00051 #endif
00052 
00053 #include "math.h" // for FC_VALUE_EQUIV macro
00054 #include "float.h" // for FC_FLOAT_EQUIV and FC_DOUBLE_EQUIV
00055 
00056 // For the Equiv tests below, the a==b might seem to be unnecessary
00057 // but it catchs the a=b=0 case so we never have divide by zero.
00058 
00059 /** \name Macros for floating point equality comparison. */
00060 //-------------------------------
00061 //@{
00062 
00063 /**
00064  * \ingroup  PublicFloatingPoint
00065  * \brief Test equality of floating point numbers
00066  *
00067  * \description 
00068  *
00069  *   This macro returns true if both values are equal (that is the
00070  *   scaled difference between them is less than epsilon) or if they
00071  *   are both essentially zero (absolute value less than min). This 
00072  *   macro should only be used with floats and doubles (and long doubles).
00073  *
00074  *   Good guess values for EPS and MIN come from float.h 
00075  *   See discussion in 'Subtraction and Comparing Floats'
00076  *   and 'Precision of Mixed Type Operations'
00077  *
00078  * \modifications
00079  *   2003-JUL-23  W Koegler  Created.
00080  *
00081  */
00082 #define FC_VALUE_EQUIV(a,   /* floating point number */ \
00083                        b,   /* floating point number */ \
00084                        EPS, /* smallest difference between numbers, scaled */ \
00085                        MIN  /* smallest number distinct from zero */ ) \
00086 ( ( (a) == (b) ) ||                                                    \
00087   ( (fabs(a) < (MIN)) && (fabs(b) < (MIN)) ) ||                        \
00088   ( fabs( ((a)-(b)) / (fabs(a) > fabs(b) ? (a) : (b)) ) < (EPS) )      \
00089 )
00090 
00091 /**
00092  * \ingroup  PublicFloatingPoint
00093  * \brief Test equality of two values with float precision
00094  *
00095  * \description 
00096  *
00097  *   This is a version of FC_VALUE_EQUIV specific for comparing values
00098  *   which have the precision of a float.
00099  *   This macro returns true if both values are equal (that is the
00100  *   scaled difference between them is less than FLT_EPSILON) or if they
00101  *   are both essentially zero (absolute value less than FLT_MIN). 
00102  *
00103  *   See discussion in 'Subtraction and Comparing Floats'
00104  *   and 'Precision of Mixed Type Operations'
00105  *
00106  * \modifications
00107  *   2003-JUL-23  W Koegler  Created.
00108  *
00109  */
00110 #define FC_FLT_EQUIV(a,   /* floating point number */ \
00111                      b    /* floating point number */ ) \
00112 ( ( (a) == (b) ) ||                                             \
00113   ( (fabs(a) < FLT_MIN) && (fabs(b) < FLT_MIN) ) ||             \
00114   ( fabs( ((a)-(b)) / (fabs(a) > fabs(b) ? (a) : (b)) ) < FLT_EPSILON ) \
00115 )
00116 
00117 /**
00118  * \ingroup  PublicFloatingPoint
00119  * \brief Test equality of two values with double precision
00120  *
00121  * \description
00122  * 
00123  *   This is a version of FC_VALUE_EQUIV specific for comparing values
00124  *   which have the precision of a double.
00125  *   This macro returns true if both values are equal (that is the
00126  *   scaled difference between them is less than DBL_EPSILON) or if they
00127  *   are both essentially zero (absolute value less than DBL _MIN). 
00128  *
00129  *   See discussion in 'Subtraction and Comparing Floats'
00130  *   and 'Precision of Mixed Type Operations'
00131  *
00132  * \modifications
00133  *   2003-JUL-23  W Koegler  Created.
00134  */
00135 #define FC_DBL_EQUIV(a,   /* floating point number */ \
00136                      b    /* floating point number */ ) \
00137 ( ( (a) == (b) ) ||                                             \
00138   ( (fabs(a) < DBL_MIN) && (fabs(b) < DBL_MIN) ) ||             \
00139   (fabs( ((a)-(b)) / (fabs(a) > fabs(b) ? (a) : (b)) ) < DBL_EPSILON )  \
00140 )
00141 
00142 //@}
00143 
00144 // floating point comparisons
00145 int fc_eq(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00146 int fc_neq(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00147 int fc_lt(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00148 int fc_lteq(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00149 int fc_gt(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00150 int fc_gteq(double x, double y, double eps,double min);
00151 int fc_eqf(double x, double y);
00152 int fc_neqf(double x, double y);
00153 int fc_ltf(double x, double y);
00154 int fc_lteqf(double x, double y);
00155 int fc_gtf(double x, double y);
00156 int fc_gteqf(double x, double y);
00157 int fc_eqd(double x, double y);
00158 int fc_neqd(double x, double y);
00159 int fc_ltd(double x, double y);
00160 int fc_lteqd(double x, double y);
00161 int fc_gtd(double x, double y);
00162 int fc_gteqd(double x, double y);

00174 #define FC_PI 3.14159265358979323846
